item.title: Report: Hitman Is No Longer Coming To 2025’s Biggest Flop
item.content:encoded:
MindsEye was one of last year’s worst-reviewed games. It was published by IO Interactive and was supposed to get a special Hitman crossover mission. According to a new report from Insider Gaming, that’s no longer happening and developer Build a Rocket Boy and IO Interactive have decided to bail on the failed joint venture. 

What this means for the future of MindsEye, once pitched as the first building block in an ambitious open-world metaverse called Everywhere, is currently unclear. But apparently the Hitman mission, the shooter’s highest-profile bit of upcoming content, is canceled. 

Build a Rocket Boy and IO Interactive didn’t immediately respond to requests for comment.

The most surprising part of Insider Gaming’s report is that Build a Rocket Boy was apparently the one pushing to end the ill-fated partnership, a decision influenced by the ex-Grand Theft Auto producer-led studio’s  “desire to bring its publishing in-house and gain more control over its future.”

IOI Interactive and Build A Rocket Boy announced the deal that would see the Hitman maker publish MindsEye, the first third-party game distributed through IOI Interactive’s IO Partners program, back in October 2024. The Hitman mission was announced onstage at Geoff Keighley’s Summer Game Fest 2025, but later delayed amid layoffs and Build a Rocket Boy’s rush to clean up MindsEye’s messy launch.

IOI Interactive CEO Hakan Abrak commented on the debacle during an interview with IGN last September. “Well, that was definitely tough, right?” he said at the time. “It was a tough reception. It wasn’t what they hoped for, and also what we didn’t hope for at IOI Partners. They’re working hard on turning that around to regain the trust of the gamers out there, and they have tons of potential and content they’re working on. So hopefully they’ll succeed with that in the future.”

Perhaps the only people who will truly be distraught at this news are the streamers and content creators who are still being paid to promote MindsEye. At least we’ll know for sure IOI Interactive had been the one bankrolling the sponsored content should the “#MindsEyePartner”-tagged streams suddenly come to an end in the near future.



https://kotaku.com/hitman-mission-mindseye-build-rocket-io-interactive-2000664566
item.dc:creator: invalid@example.com (ResetEra_Newsbot

item.title: Developers Hate AI, Want Unions, And Are Abandoning Xbox According To This New Survey
item.content:encoded:
The 2026 Game Developers Conference (GDC), which has been renamed the GDC Festival of Gaming, takes place in early March. Ahead of the San Francisco-based industry event, GDC has released its annual survey of game industry developer sentiment. Over 2,300 industry professionals responded on topics ranging from genAI to layoffs, providing a small snapshot of what’s going on across video game companies big and small. It’s not a pretty picture.

A majority of game developers now think genAI will hurt the game industry

Back in 2024, game makers were relatively split on the advantages and downsides of the emerging LLM craze. Now they are increasingly horrified by it. Last year, 13 percent of respondents thought genAI would have a positive impact on the game industry. In 2026 it’s just 7 percent. Instead, 52 percent think the technology will have a negative impact, up double digits from just 12 months ago. Artists, storytellers, programmers–they’re all down on it. Still, actual adoption of the technology for things as simple as writing emails is growing.

Developers are bailing on making games for Xbox

According to the new survey, roughly 40 percent of respondents said they were interested in making their next game for PlayStation 5 or Switch 2. Only 20 percent were planning to bring it to Xbox Series X/S. That’s still above Android, iOS, and the original Switch, but it’s a steep drop-off from last year when the Xbox number was 34 percent. PC is still far and away the most popular platform. Maybe that’s why Microsoft is pivoting to it.

Union support is surging

Over 80 percent of U.S.-based developers told the survey they support unionization, with 62 percent saying they were interested in joining one. Those numbers show there’s likely room for many more game studios to organize, as only 13 percent of respondents said they’re actually currently in a union. Union drives have been sweeping through Microsoft-owned subsidiaries thanks to a neutrality clause the company previously agreed to, but unions have struggled to take hold at many other big publishers like Electronic Arts and 2K Games.

A third of U.S. developers said they were laid off in the last two years

That’s a devastating number which shows that the full impact of the recent downsizing spree will still be with the industry for years to come. Meanwhile, 17 percent of respondents said they were laid off within the last 12 months, a steady annual increase over the previous two years. Even worse, nearly 50 percent of people laid off weren’t able to find another job in the video game industry during that time.

Trump take game

The administration’s trade war and anti-immigrant crackdown appears to be taking a real toll on the game industry. According to the survey, 31 percent of respondents canceled travel plans to the U.S. while another third are currently reconsidering future travel. A whopping 60 percent of non-U.S. industry leaders said the policies had negatively impacted their desire to conduct business based in the country. On the trade side, 38 percent of respondents said tariffs had impacted their financial decisions.



https://kotaku.com/gdc-2026-survey-ai-union-layoff-xbox-ps5-trump-2000664245
item.dc:creator: invalid@example.com (ResetEra_Newsbot

item.title: Skip Expensive Flowers, LEGO Roses Drop Under $10 With Nearly 40% Off Ahead of Valentine’s Day
item.content:encoded:
Valentine’s Day is just around the corner, and what better way to show your love than flowers that you can build together and never have to replace? We’re talking about LEGO roses, which aren’t just a sweet gesture, but also look incredibly beautiful and require zero upkeep.

If you haven’t picked a gift up yet, or are looking for a second one, the LEGO Roses set is available for just under $10 at Amazon, after a nice $5 discount. It’s a great time to grab one without overspending, and even pick up a few, because a bouquet never hurts.

See at Amazon

Quick to Build

It’s not one of those massive builds that takes days and weeks to complete. LEGO keeps it short and sweet with this one. You’re getting a total of just 120 pieces, which come together to make two beautiful roses with adjustable stems. The stem of each rose measures over 10 in. (26 cm) long, so it’s perfect for displaying in a vase. You can plan a cute LEGO date around building these with your partner, while also asking each other thoughtful questions for a meaningful conversation, or go down memory lane together. Maybe stream a cute, romantic movie as you build – the possibilities are endless!

These are great as Valentine’s Day gifts, but also make a thoughtful present for Mother’s Day, Women’s Day, birthdays, and anniversaries. You can even treat yourself to a set because hey, you need to appreciate yourself too.

Building these is pretty straightforward. The set comes with a detailed instruction booklet that takes you through each step one-by-one. The book includes visuals to assist you, which makes the process even easier. LEGO also has its own building app – the LEGO Builder – which offers 3D instructions. You can zoom in on the blocks from each angle to understand the steps better. The app also lets you track your progress, build with friends, and save sets.

You can now grab the LEGO Roses set for just under $10, after Amazon took $5 off its usual $15 price. If you’re open to spending a bit more, it’s also worth checking out other sets in LEGO’s Botanical collection. Several options are discounted right now, so you can mix and match flowers for a fuller, more colorful bouquet!

See at Amazon



https://kotaku.com/skip-expensive-flowers-lego-roses-drop-under-10-with-nearly-40-off-ahead-of-valentines-day-2000663278
